Award.AwardTitle: Psychological Reactions to Foreign Cultures: Effects of Simultaneous Activation of Cultures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Globalization has increased the frequency and intensity of exposure to other cultures. The research proposed here seeks to identify the social cognitive principles that explain and predict variations in people's psychological reactions when they are exposed to foreign culture. Exposure to foreign cultures may produce a broad range of psychological impacts, from inciting exclusionary, nationalist sentiments to inspiring novel, creative ideas. In the proposed research, the psychological impacts of foreign cultural exposure will be studied in a laboratory setting. Six experiments using an innovative paradigm will examine the psychological effects of simultaneous activation of cultures. In this paradigm, iconic priming is used to activate representations of two cultures simultaneously. It is hypothesized that stereotype-consistent information about a culture will be encoded elaborately and remembered well and that previously encoded information will be assimilated into the cultural stereotypes. In addition, the researcher proposes to test several other hypotheses including the self-categorization hypothesis, the cultural learning hypothesis, and the serial reproduction hypothesis. By focusing on the social cognitive consequences of simultaneous activation of culture, findings from this work will promote a new behavioral science perspective on current debates arising over the psychological impacts of intercultural contacts in the context of globalization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In most parts of the world, globalization has become an unstoppable and potent force that impacts everyday life and international relations. During on insights from social psychology, we found that despite regional differences in experiences with globalization, people in different parts of the world have similar understanding of globalization. They perceived globalization to be related to but not synonymous with modernization, Westernization, and Americanization; used international trade versus technology, and globalization of consumption versus global consequences as the dimensions to categorize globalization-related issues; and perceived globalization to have stronger positive effects on people’s competence than on their warmth.

We further show with globalization, people are more frequently exposed to multiple cultures in the same space and at the same time. These perceptual experiences increase the tendency for people to use culture as a framework for organizing perceptions in intercultural contexts. Once culture becomes a salient perceptual framework for organizing perceptions, individuals become more creative when they are motivated to see foreign cultures as intellectual resources, and more likely to resist foreign cultural influence when they see foreign cultures as contaminants of their heritage culture. The likelihood that individuals would exhibit exclusionary reactions to foreign cultures increases when individuals experience existential anxiety and decreases when they are motivated to engage in thoughtful cultural reflections. Finally, the likelihood that individuals would learn from foreign cultures will increase among who are open-minded.
